intro: Corydalis curviflora var. pseudosmithii, commonly known as the Sierra foothill corydalis, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Fumariaceae family and typically grows in rocky or open habitats. The plant features delicate, slender stems and produces clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers in shades of pink or purple. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a hairy texture, contributing to its distinctive appearance. This variety is noted for its ornamental value and is sometimes cultivated in gardens for its aesthetic appeal.
